turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: I told her I loved her.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: By way of saying you were unhappy.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Restless.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Excuse me.  'Things are so confusing for me, Jack.  Our life feels too comfortable, too safe, too predict- able.  It's a partnership, it's juggling schedules.  When I think of playing that out, every day, for the rest of my life...'

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: '...I don't know if I can make it.' That's what I said.  But I didn't leave.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: No, she threw you out.  What a difficult woman.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: That's a pretty ugly thing you just said.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: No, here's ugly.  'I love <u>you</u>, babe. It's just our <u>life</u> together I'm not so sure about...'

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: 'But keep dancing, and if you're lucky, I might just never leave, who knows?'

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: That's not us.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Because you've changed so much.

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: We make our lives, one step at a time.  We do the best we can.  The truth about the future?  A promise. Is only a hope.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: How about the promises we make to our kids?  About <u>their</u> future.  Do we shrug those off, just that easily?

turns.speaker: LUKE
turns.text: Where you goin'?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I'm gonna get me a drink.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Hi, I'm here to pick up Ben.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Does Jackie know this?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: No.  I'm doing it behind her back.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: In seven years Jackie's never missed one of Tucker's parties. Where is she?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Something came up.  C'mon Ben! I've got a shoot at three...

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Tucker hasn't penned Ben's present yet -- it won't be too much longer.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I don't know what's wrong with that kid.

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: Maybe he's gay.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Don't ever say that.

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: What if he is?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: He isn't.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Out! Leave the table!

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You heard me: leave the table!

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: Man, I am out of here! This family is so fucked!

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: We're studying the Holocaust in Social Studies.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh, yeah?

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: Well, I'm supposed to watch Schindler's List for homework. The movie's like almost four hours. And then I'm supposed to write a report on survivors.  You know any survivors, Dad?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hmmm...Do I know any...personally...?

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: Hey.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Hey. What's up?

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: There's something I need to talk about with you.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: There are some rumors...

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: You know...Stanley...

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: And like, don't take this the wrong way...I mean, I'm cool...but...you know...I've got a good reputation at school and, well...I really don't want it ruined.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: No prob. I'm cool.

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: Thanks, Scoob.

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Marty, ignore him.

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: He's vegetarian, doesn't do sports...

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Well, technically your Zeda is a survivor.

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: He was in a concentration camp?

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Well, no. But he had to escape the Nazis.

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: But I thought he came over to America before the war.

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Well, he did. With his family. But his cousins, they had to stay and they were all killed. And if he'd stayed, he would have been killed. So in my book he's a survivor.

turns.speaker: BRADY
turns.text: Even though it was only his cousins that were killed?

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: But that could've happened to him. Or to me, if I'd been alive. Or you.

turns.speaker: CONAN
turns.text: Hey, Scooby! How's it going?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Conan O'Brien? Whoa! What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: CONAN
turns.text: I'm looking for a last-minute guest for my show. Any suggestions?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: I'll be your guest!

turns.speaker: CONAN
turns.text: Really? Well, all right! Let's take a look at the television and see how we look.

turns.speaker: CONAN
turns.text: Welcome to the show, Scooby.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: CONAN
turns.text: Nice to have you here.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Great to be here.

turns.speaker: CONAN
turns.text: And thank you for dressing up for us. This is very classy. Tell us. What kind of professional plans do you have? What's in your future?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Well, I was thinking...I might work for you.

turns.speaker: CONAN
turns.text: Ahh...tell me. What do you want to do for me? What's your idea?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Be your sidekick, you know, and maybe eventually become a TV talk- show host.

turns.speaker: CONAN
turns.text: TV talk-show host, OK. You were at sidekick eight seconds ago, then TV talk-show host. You'll be a Latin dictator in a bout a minute.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Consuelo?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: Yes, Mikey?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Do you have any brothers or sisters?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Really? How many?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: Four brothers and five sisters.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Wow.  Why did your parents have so many children? I mean, if they were poor, wouldn't it be better to have just one or two?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: It was God's will.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: But do you really believe in God? And heaven, hell and angels and all kind of stuff?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: When I'm in high school I'm not going to play any football. I'm just going to concentrate on class rank.  What did you do in high school?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: I did not go to high school.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Weren't there high schools in El Salvador?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: We had to work. My family was poor.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Must've been hard being poor.

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: I'm still poor.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Hmmm.  But, Consuelo, even though your poor, don't you have any hobbies or interests or anything?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: No, Mikey.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: But like, what do you like to do when you're not working?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: I'm always working.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: But when you're not. Like now. What do you like to do?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: This is work.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: But it's not like real work. This is just babysitting.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Consuelo. Are you crying?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Yes, you are. I can tell. What's the matter?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: Mi Jesusmi jesus

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Speak English.

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: Mi Jesus esta muerto!

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Consuelo, I'm sorry, but you know if you don't speak English I can't understand you.

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: My Jesus

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Who is Jesus?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: My baby.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: You have a bay?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: My grandchild-baby.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Gee, I didn't even know you had any children. But why are you so upset about Jesus?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: He's dead.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Oh. How did it happen?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: He was executed. He was on Death Row and then he was executed.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: How did they execute him?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: Poison gas.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Maybe it's for the bestI mean, if he was guilty of doing  something wrongPeople who are bad should be killed. Don't you think so?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: Jesus was not bad.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Maybe he was and you just didn't know it.

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: He wasn't.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: But still, you can't be sure.

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: I am sure.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: But really, you never know.

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: I know!

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Why was he on Death Row?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: For rape and murder.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Consuelo, what is rape exactly?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: It is when you love someone, and they don't love you. And then you do something about it.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Sometimes I feel like my parents don't love me.

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: Well then, when you get older you can do something about it.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: So whaddya think?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: Well, I'm not really sure what you're trying to say. It's funny, I suppose. But it seems glib and facile to just make fun of how idiotic these people are.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: I'm not making fun. I'm showing it as it really is.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: You're showing how superior you are to your subject. TOBY No, but I like my subject. I like these people.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: No, you don't.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Yes, I do. I love them!

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: The camerawork's nice.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Thanks. I'll tell Mike.  Well, it's still just a beginning. I know I can...dig deeper.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: This is definitely better.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: You think so? You don't think that this might not be a little dry?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: This is entertainment you're making, Toby. This story about a kid in the suburbs and the state of the college admissions process has, with this Brady crisis, evolved into something much richer and more provocative.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Yes, I knowBut still, it should be somewhat entertaining.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: I mean, without this footage, without this rigorous documentation, it would feel like exploitation.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: No, no, no. No exploitation. This is seriousBut don't you find it a little funny too, at the same time?

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: You've got a family tragedy on your hands. Will you tell me what's funny about that? About a kid in a coma?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Nothing, I guess

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: I mean, why are you making this documentary if you can't treat your subject with appropriate gravity?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: OK, you're right, you're right  You know, we need to screen what we've gotinvite some regular people, just some random off-the- street typesand see what real people think of this.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: I dunno, Toby. We really have a long way to go. You still need a lot more footage, and it's probably a little premature to start screening

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: OK, then we can invite serious intellectual types.

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: We're not ready.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Hip alternative types who will understand the process better

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: We're not ready!

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Well, I need to see this with an audience!

turns.speaker: EDITOR
turns.text: What's an audience going to tell you?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: I don't know. Maybe they'll like it.

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Don't even joke about that!

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: I'm serious! What happens if he blows up the school?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Twinkeys!

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Boys, take napkins...Napkins...

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Mom?

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Yes, Mikey?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: I was looking through Scooby's SATs practice books this afternoon and I took one of the practice tests. Guess what score I got?

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: 550 verbal, 520 math. And I'm only in fifth grade!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Steak's really good tonight. SCOOBY  Good.

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Got a lot of homework?

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Marty...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: You started filling out your college applications yet?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Not to be crass, but what do we get out of this?

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Don't worry, he doesn't mean money.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: We used pull.

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: You know, you have to. Sometimes you just have to, Toby.

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: It's all about who you know.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Look, we're not suckers. Everyone else is out there doing the same thing.

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: He's right.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Sure!...

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Of course, honey. Come in bed with us. Come on.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Was anyone in my room today?

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Is everything OK?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: My CD case like totally collapsed. I'm gonna have to recatalogue all weekend.  Hey. Can you pass the salad over.

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: I dunno.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: We did the same thing last year also.

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: How was the class?

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Well...yes. If it hadn't been for Hitler, he wouldn't have had to leave Europe. We would have been...European.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: But then, in a sense, since you would never have met Dad if your family had stayed in Europe...if it weren't for Hitler, none of us would have been born.

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Hi, Scooby! How was school today?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: Ready for tomorrow?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: What's tomorrow?

turns.speaker: FERN
turns.text: The SATs, knucklehead. SCOOBY I'm not taking them.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Hey, you want to hear my short story now?

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: I can read it to you.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: You mean, again?

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Well, I changed the ending a little.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Oh. What happens now?

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Well, actually, it's the same, but longer. I think it's better. More...raw.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Well then, maybe you should just read the ending.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: But it won't make any sense if you hear it out of context.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: I think you should leave it the way it was. It was good.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: So you don't want to hear my new ending?

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: You'll read it in class tomorrow. Surprise me.  Anyway, I have to go. I promised Melinda I'd help her with her oral.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: You're tired of me. I can tell.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Marcus, I'm tired. That's all.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: You've lost interest...You hardly even sweat any more when we have sex.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: I was never much of a sweater. You know that.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Look, Vi, I don't blame you. You feel You feel pity now. The pleasure isn't there any more. The kinkiness has gone...You've become kind.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Don't be so upset. It's OK...

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: What the fuck are you talking about? What's OK?

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: You know he hated my story also.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Your story was terrible!

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Marcus...You'll write something better next time!

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Patronizing fuck! If you had just been honest with me in the first place I wouldn't have read it. I knew it was shit. But - idiot! - I believed you!

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: That's not fair! I was honest! Just because I wasn't sucking up like 	that bitch Catherine.

turns.speaker: MARCUS
turns.text: Well, I sure didn't hear you voice your opinion in there when it mattered.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: I admit it - I was scared! I was shocked, in fact , by what he said. And he's so...convincing. I'm sorry if I let you down, but really, I still say he's just one opinion. I don't even like his books that much. They're all so aggressively confrontational. I don't care if he's won the Pulitzer Prize.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Which is it? You gotta keep your focus straight.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: You're absolutely right. The focus is on the college admissions process today.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: And you want Scooby to be the focus of all this?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Scooby and a few other students of different socioeconomic backgrounds.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Oh, well, I don't have them yet, but 

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Reconceive.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: 'Cause Scooby does have a quality that I've been looking for, a quality that is emblematic of American today. It's part disillusionment, part hope...

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Oh, I know, I know that. Well, sharing your story, your ups and downs, and so forth, can I hope, be an illuminating experience.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah...How do we know we won't be exploited?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: But what kind of pull did you have?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I have a cousin. Very big giver to the alumni fund.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I think Scooby's like a lot of kids. He just hit aa speed bump. Now he's gonna find his way, his path is gonna be cleared, and I think he's gonna continue his education at a good college. And everybody else is gonna be happy.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: ...But Mr Livingston, aren't you a bit fearful that Scooby will be confronted with hollow values and systemic conformism?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Fuck!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I'm going in there.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: I dunno.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Whaddya mean you don't know? You either got a lot or you don't. What's not to know?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: What DO you know?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Dad, I'm trying to figure things out right now, OK? It's like, really hard, and I'm just listening to some old Elton John and...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: So? How was school today?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: The same.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: The same. Same as what?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Just the same.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Get the hell outta here!

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Man, it's just, like, conversation.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Scooby?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: We have to talk.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Whaddya wanna talk about?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Don't screw around with me. You know what I'm talking about.  You're taking those SATs. You're taking those SATs or your CD collection is history. You're taking those SATs and you're going to college. You're taking those SATs if I have to strap your ass to a chair, but buddy your taking them.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Tired of this shit...

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: I just want to know what the hell he's doing in his room that's so interesting he doesn't come down for dinner.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Maybe he's building a bomb...just like-!

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Mom, it's not fair if Brady can say the f-word and I can't.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah, well, Mikey, listen up. Cause here's a lesson: life's not fair.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Dad?Do you think that Brady will ever get better?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: One in a million recover.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Maybe he's that one in a million!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Mikey, there's optimism, and then there's stupidity. It's a very fine line.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: I don't think there's any hope, either. I was just trying to make you feel better.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: You're welcome.  Dad?Would you let me try hypnotizing you now?

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah. Sure Go ahead. Hypnotize me.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: OK. Stay there. I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hey, Mikey. You wanna get some ice cream?

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: OK!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Hey, Mikey!

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Hi, Dad!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Come here, give me a hug!

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Gee, you're home early!

turns.speaker: MARTY
turns.text: Yeah, uh, listen. Why don't you go upstairs and keep your Mom and Brady company for a bit? I need to speak alone with Consuelo for a moment.

turns.speaker: MIKEY
turns.text: Sure, Dad.

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: Hello, Vi.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: I'm sorry. I didn't mean, I just didn't expect to run into you here, that's all.

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: Well, now you have.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Yeah, um, then...are you alone?

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: Uh huh.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Can I join you?

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: You're not.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Good.  'Cause I...um...I really agreed with everything you had to say last week about how bad my story was...

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: That's good.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: And I also agreed with what you said today about Marcus's story. It is a piece of shit.

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: You have beautiful skin.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Thank you.  So Catherine seems like she might become a really good writer.

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: Maybe. She's OK.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Aren't you going out with Catherine?  I'm sorry. It's none of my business. I didn't mean...

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: I'm not 'going out' with Catherine.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Oh.  Do you think I have a potential as a writer?

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Thank you for being honest.

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: It's over there.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: It's a really nice place you have. Is the rent high?

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: Take off your top.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Oh, bu...uh...I can't say that.

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: Say, Ni...

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Ni...

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: ...gger.

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: ...gger.

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: Say, 'Nigger.'

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Nigger.

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: 'Fuck me hard!'

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Fuck me hard!

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: Say, 'Nigger, fuck me hard!'

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Nigger, fuck me hard!

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: Again!

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: Nigger, fuck me hard!!...

turns.speaker: MR SCOTT
turns.text: Again!!

turns.speaker: VI
turns.text: NIGGER, FUCK ME HARD!!!...

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: No, not really.

turns.speaker: MR. DEMARCO
turns.text: Any books you like to read for fun?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MR. DEMARCO
turns.text: None at all? How about those 'underground' comics?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: I hate reading.

turns.speaker: MR. DEMARCO
turns.text: All right, Scooby, let's not beat around the bush. With your attitude, you're not going to get in anywhere.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: MR. DEMARCO
turns.text: 'OK.' So you just don't care.  Let me ask you, not as your guidance counselor, but...as a friend: what do you want to do with your life? I mean, what kind of long-term goals can you possibly have?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: I dunno...

turns.speaker: MR. DEMARCO
turns.text: C'mon. Talk to me. Tell me what you're thinking.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Well, I mean...I wanna be on TV. Maybe have a talk show or something. Like Conan. Or early Letterman.

turns.speaker: MR. DEMARCO
turns.text: Ah-hah. And how is it you hope to achieve this goal?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: I dunno. See if I have any connections.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Hello, is this Pam?

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Who is this?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Toby Oxman.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Toby -? Oh, hi! How are you?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Oh, fine. How are you?

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Great!

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Great!

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: So what's going on?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: That's what I was gonna ask you.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: But...you called.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Oh, yeah, well...um...I was just calling because, well, I was wondering if you still remembered me, which I guess you do...

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: So. Look at where we are: the year 2000! Can you believe it? I mean, did you ever think we would actually make it?

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Um, well, yeah.  So are you still acting?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Oh, no, not any more. No, um, I kind of came to terms with myself, I realized I had done what I had to do. And it was time to move on.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Oh. So what did you do after you gave up on acting?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Well, I went to law school, if you can believe that.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: I believe it.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Yeah, well, it was really all kind of a joke - and a rip-off, so, uh...so I dropped out.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Oh, that's too bad.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Yeah, well, then it got me writing, so that was a good thing.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Anything I might know about?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Well, um, I kind of let things go on this novel I'd been really into - I mean, the whole publishing industry is totally corrupt. I mean, really, it's finished.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: That's too bad.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: I worked over at a homeless shelter for a while, drove a cab to pay the rent, but, I mean, that was like - I mean, I have some dignity.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: That's good. So then what do you do now?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: I'm a documentary filmmaker.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Oh? Anything I might have seen?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: N-not yet. I'm hoping to get a grant for this one project on teenagers. Geez, remember when we were teenagers?

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Yeah. You didn't wanna take me to the prom.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Oh, I don't remember that...

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: I do.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Well, but it was so long ago. We were so different back then...

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Uh, well, anyway, so I'm looking for subjects for this documentary on teenage life in suburbia. Kind of an exploration of the mental psyche of its mythology. I wrote to Derrida to see if he'd like to do the narration. But everything's still kind of in development at this point.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Hunh.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: That's good.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Yeah...um...so anyway, tell me. What about you? I'd heard through the grapevine you were producing movies.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Yeah. But not any more.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Oh. Tired of 'life in the fast lane'?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Yeah...So you're um...you're married?

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Huh. Kids?

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: How many?

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Three.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Great. How old are they?

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Eight, six, and four.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Wow, that really is great. In a few years, who knows, maybe they'll want to be in my documentary!

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: Listen, Toby, I can't really talk right now. Do you mind if I call you back?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Yeah, sure.

turns.speaker: PAM
turns.text: OK. Bye.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Maybe she has caller ID.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Pretty cool, Stanley.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: How'd you get it?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: It's my Dad's He hides it under some old TV Guides in his closet.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Gee, your Dad's smart.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Is it loaded?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: No, I don't think so...

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Scooby, don't! Be careful!

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: I'm not an idiot, man. I watch TV.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: I Know. I'm sorry. I'm just...a little nervous, I don't know why.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: You should be.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Scooby?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: You know...I like you.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Yeah. I know.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: I mean...

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: You want some?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: No, thanks.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: You a pervert?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: No...Actually, I'm a documentary filmmaker?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Oh. You mean, like, Blair Witch Project?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Well, no. I'm doing one on high school students, in fact.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Well...it's kind of a sociological study in the aftermath of Columbine.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Is this to like get into Sundance?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Yeah, well, it's possible they would be interested in it.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Doubt it.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Actually, there is some interest from the Sundance Channel.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Whoopee.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: HBO and MTV have also shown some interest.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: So like, yeahI caved in. I mean, I had to. My parents, they're like still really depressed about Brady. So I wrote the bullshit essay. Filled out the applications, did the interviewsY'know, I figure I can always drop out.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: So where'd you get in?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Prnceton.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: But what did you get on your SATs?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: 200 verbal/710 math. Kinda weird, I know. But I think they thought it was, like, good-weird.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Hey, um, Toby? I was wonderingIs the documentary almost finished?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Uh, yeah, we're getting there.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Can I see what you have so far?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Sureumyeah, as soon as I have a screening I'll let you know.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Thanks man.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: What is most important to you?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: I dunno. I'd like to be good at something. It doesn't have to be TV. I mean, it could be movies...Anything. I'd be willing to direct.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Uh, Scooby, now I understand how you want to be a TV talk-show host and all, like Conan O'Brien, but did you know even he went to college?

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: He did?

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Yeah. He went to Harward.

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: TOBY
turns.text: Oh, my God, Scooby! I'm so sorry...I'm so, so sorry...

turns.speaker: SCOOBY
turns.text: Don't be. Your movie's a hit.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Henry, what exactly are these crazed gunmen demanding?

turns.speaker: ALONZO
turns.text: Th-they want t-twenty-f-five million dollars cash--or Chemco will be destroyed.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Twenty-five-million!  And what will they do if the money isn't delivered?

turns.speaker: ALONZO
turns.text: Th-th-they'll kill one hostage every hour until it is--

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Does that include Helen Filmore, United States congresswoman?

turns.speaker: ALONZO
turns.text: Y-yes--

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Uh-oh!  Do you know if the demands are being taken seriously at this point, or does Washington think these people are just a bunch of crazy fuckers playing games?

turns.speaker: ALONZO
turns.text: Well, I-I hope that--that--

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Times up!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I don't know what hit us!  We had them trapped on the stairwell.  They could be anywhere now.

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: I now understand the expression "you get what you pay for!" A bunch of chumps!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: Listen man, I don't need this shit--

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: We got trouble.  That bodyguard son- of-a-bitch has them running all over the field--just took out three on the north end!

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Well get someone down there!

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: There isn't anyone! He's opened that whole sector now!

turns.speaker: RICHTER
turns.text: Is he with the girl?

turns.speaker: BURNS
turns.text: I don't know--look!  They can get in now, man!  We got no one left to guard it!

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I'll lead.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: Why? Are we going dancing?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I said I'll lead.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: What are you going to do, Cooper, throw yourself on a Bunsen burner? It's a bunch of businessmen touring a lab.  We'll be out in no time.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I gotta keep you alive--it's in my contract.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: If you're working for me you're going to do what I tell you.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: Just get me a coke and don't argue with me, OK?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I'm not arguing.  I'm just telling you what the deal is--Congresswoman.

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: Look Cooper I don't care what my father says, if you embarrass me here you're going to regret it, understand?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Anything else?  Maybe a sandwich?

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: Just the soda, please. Cooper heads down the hall.  Filmore watches him leave, sighs, then turns and smiles at the General manager:

turns.speaker: FILMORE
turns.text: What are we going to do!

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Who's got matches?
